meta.title: Coordinate Geometry - Exercise 3.2 (Short Answer Questions with Reasoning)

questions.question: Write whether the following statements are True or False? Justify your answer.
parts: (i) Point $(3, 0)$ lies in the first quadrant.
(ii) Points $(1, -1)$ and $(-1, 1)$ lie in the same quadrant.
(iii) The coordinates of a point whose ordinate is $-\frac{1}{2}$ and abscissa is $1$ are $(-\frac{1}{2}, 1)$.
(iv) A point lies on y-axis at a distance of 2 units from the x-axis. Its coordinates are $(2, 0)$.
(v) $(-1, 7)$ is a point in the II quadrant.
questions.solution:
(i) False. The ordinate of the point $(3, 0)$ is zero. Therefore, the point lies on the x-axis, not in the first quadrant.

(ii) False. The point $(1, -1)$ has a positive abscissa and negative ordinate, so it lies in the IV quadrant. The point $(-1, 1)$ has a negative abscissa and positive ordinate, so it lies in the II quadrant. They are in different quadrants.

(iii) False. The coordinates of a point are written as (abscissa, ordinate). Here, abscissa $= 1$ and ordinate $= -\frac{1}{2}$. So, the coordinates are $(1, -\frac{1}{2})$.

(iv) False. A point lying on the y-axis has its abscissa (x-coordinate) as 0. Since it is at a distance of 2 units from the x-axis, its ordinate is either 2 or -2. Thus, the coordinates are $(0, 2)$ or $(0, -2)$. The point $(2, 0)$ lies on the x-axis.

(v) True. In the point $(-1, 7)$, the abscissa is negative ($-1$) and the ordinate is positive ($7$). Points with $(-x, y)$ form lie in the II quadrant.
